page.title: 05LOCAL HISTORY,SOUTH FEN
page.content: As one might expect, there is much local history to be gleaned from the names of the two hamlets in this area, Tongue End and Twenty. The name 'Tongue End' originates from the shape made by the river Glen at the hamlet where it meets its confluence, the river Bourne Eau. It had previously been known both as 'Adventurers Land' (derived from the Dutch who first came to drain the land) and later as 'Little Britain'. The hamlet of Twenty came with the new railway which built a station in the close proximity known as 'Bourne North Fen'. However, due to the near- ness of Bourne itself it was decided to change the name of the former with the railway company adopting the number of the nearest mile post, hence the name'Twenty';twenty miles from the mainline at Saxby, near Melton, Leics.
